<br>
.pull-left[
<div style="text-align:left">
<span style="color:green">[sorcerer]</span> and <span style="color:green">[TA]</span><br>

<span style="color:blue"><b>/Merlin/</b></span> → <span style="color:green">[sorcerer]</span> / _ (when saving the world)<br>

.pull-right[
**phoneme**: a set of sounds that speakers of a language treat as being the same (<span style="color:blue"><b><i>/t/</i></b></span>)<br><br>

**allophone**: each individual possible sound that a phoneme could surface as  (<span style="color:blue"><b><i>[t<sup>h</sup>]</i></b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b><i>[t]</i></b></span>) <br><br>

<span style="color:green"><b>contrastive distribution</b></span>: switching out one *phoneme* for another results in a different meaning
- these word pairs are called **minimal pairs**
- they detect which sounds are **phonemes**<br><br>

<span style="color:green"><b>complementary distribution</b></span>: switching a sound out for another one *does not* change the meaning
- they are **allophones** of the same phoneme
]

## **Phonological Processes**
<br>
.pull-left[
**assimilation**
- a sound segment changes to become <span style="color:blue"><b>more similar</b></span> to another nearby sound segment
- we can measure in terms of comparing their features
- <b>English</b> plural /-s/ → [z] after a <span style="color:green"><b>voiced</b></span> stop
  - [k<sup>h</sup>æt**s**], vs. [dɔg**z**]<br><br>

**dissimilation**
- a sound changes to become <span style="color:blue"><b>less similar</b></span> to another segment
- <b>Latin</b> to <b>English</b> loanword
  - [pe**r**eg**r**inu] → [pi<span style="color:green"><b>l</b></span>g**r**im]
- The first **[r]** dissimilates to an <span style="color:green"><b>[l]</b></span> to become less like the second **[r]**<br><br>
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/1205/same.jpg" width="90%">
<br><br>

]

## **Phonological Processes**
<br>
.pull-left[
<br>
<div style="text-align:center";>
<img src="../pic/1121/cat.jpg" width="75%">]
</div>
.pull-right[
**insertion/epenthesis**
- a sound segment is <span style="color:blue"><b>added</b></span> to a word
- <b>English</b> glide insertion
  - '*I am*', '*see it*', '*do it*', '*you and I*'<br><br>

**deletion/elision:** 
- a sound is <span style="color:blue"><b>removed</b></span> from a word
- <b>English</b>
  - rock <span style="color:green"><b>[ænd]</b></span> roll → rock <span style="color:green"><b>[n]</b></span> roll
- <b>Kazakh</b> vowel hiatus resolution
  - [sa.r**ɯ** **ɑ**r.ba] → [sa.r**ɑ**r.ba] ('yellow trolley')<br><br>

**strengthening/weakening**
- sound segments get <span style="color:green"><b>"*stronger*"</b></span> or <span style="color:orange"><b>"*weaker*"</b></span> in terms of the **Sonority Scale**</b></span>
]

## **Phonological Processes**
<br>
.pull-left[
<div style="text-align:center";>
<img src="../pic/1205/capy.jpg" width="80%">
</div>]
.pull-right[
**strengthening**
- sound segments get <span style="color:green"><b>"*stronger*"</b></span> in terms of the **Sonority Scale**</b></span>
- in some varieties of <b>American English</b>
  - [wɪ<span style="color:green"><b>θ</b></span>] → [wɪ<span style="color:blue"><b>t</b></span>] ('*with*')
  - [<span style="color:green"><b>θ</b></span>ɛm] → [<span style="color:orange"><b>d</b></span>ɛm] ('*them*')
  - (fricative → stop)<br><br>

**weakening**
- sound segments get <span style="color:orange"><b>"*weaker*"</b></span> in terms of the **Sonority Scale**</b></span>
- again, in <b>American English</b>
  - <span style="color:green"><b>/t/</b></span> → <span style="color:blue"><b>[ɾ]</b></span> in *butter*, *better*, *water*
  - <span style="color:green"><b>/t/</b></span> becomes voiced and is no longer a stop
]

  - <span style="color:blue"><b>[ɪŋ]</b></span> in *incredible, ingratitude*<br><br>
3. "tsunami" is pronounced: , but  it is often pronounced 
  - **[t͡sunami]** in <b>Japanese</b>, but

  - "**al**" in *naval*, *vocal*, *capital*, *coronal*, and

3. <b>English</b>
  - <span style="color:blue"><b>[ɾ]</b></span> in *atom* [æɾəm], *metal* [mɛɾəl] becomes
  - <span style="color:green"><b>[t<sup>h</sup>]</b></span> in *atomic* [ətʰɑmɪk], *metallic* [mətʰælik]

## **Step-by-Step Phonological Analysis**
<br>
.pull-left[
1. write the preceding and following segment (<span style="color:green"><b>environment</b></span>) for **the sound you're testing**<br><br>
2. do they occur in the same or different environments?
  - **same**: *contrastive* → separate phonemes
  - **different**: *complementary* → allophones<br><br>
3. consider the  <span style="color:blue"><b>commonality</b></span> of environments of allophones<br><br>
4. <span style="color:orange"><b>simplify</b></span> the environments (*V_V*, *#_C*, etc.) <br><br>
5. rewrite simplified environments as <span style="color:deeppink"><b>phonological rules</b></span>
]
.pull-right[<br>
<table style="width:70%; border-collapse: collapse; margin:auto; font-size:24px;">
  <tr>
    <th style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:10px; text-align:center;"><span style="color:orange"><b>d</b></span></th>
    <th style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:10px; text-align:center;"><span style="color:blue"><b>ð</b></span></th>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:20px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top;">
      [#_a]<br>
      [#_e]<br>
      [#_a]<br>
      [#_u]<br>
      [#_e]<br>
      [#_e]<br>
    </td>
    <td style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:20px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top;">
      [o_o]<br>
      [i_a]<br>
      [o_o]<br>
      [u_a]<br>
      [a_o]<br>
      [e_o]<br>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
<br><br>
  - /d/ → d / #__
  - /d/ → ð / V__V
]
